Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Re : Formal Dispute Letter for Immediate Removal of Inaccurate Accounts To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute the following inaccurate information that appears on my credit report. I have thoroughly reviewed my credit report and have found multiple discrepancies and unverified accounts that are negatively impacting my credit score. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am requesting an immediate reinvestigation of these items and immediate removal from my credit report. 

The details of the disputed items are as follows : XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$170.00} - This account lacks a conspicuously listed address as required under FCRA Section 623 ; therefore, it can not legally be reported. Remove this immediately. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX - Account # : XXXX - This account was reported without valid evidence in violation of FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( 7 ). Please remove it immediately. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$1900.00} - Reported without valid verification in violation of FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( 7 ). Immediate removal is demanded. 

XXXX. XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$780.00} - No documentation has been provided to verify this collection account. Remove it immediately. 

XXXX. XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$0.00} - There is no evidence justifying the reporting of this account. Immediate removal is requested. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$1600.00} - Information found to be inaccurate or unverifiable must be deleted as per 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( 5 ). Take prompt action to correct my file. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$290.00} & {$0.00} respectively - These accounts are not recognized by me and I have received no communication regarding them. They must be removed without delay. And both have the same account number different balance. 

XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$310.00} - This debt has not been validated, thus it violates FCRA provisions. Remove it at once. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$310.00} - Reported as ID theft to the original creditor. It should not be reported ; remove immediately. 

XXXX. XXXX - Account # : XXXX - XXXX : {$570.00} - I am unfamiliar with this account ; see the attached police report. Please remove it. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$220.00} - Reporting is unsupported by valid evidence, violating FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( 7 ). Reinvestigate and delete this item. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX - Account # : XXXX - XXXX : {$110.00} - Lack of a conspicuously listed address necessitates immediate removal of this collection account as per Section 623. 

XXXX. XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$610.00} - Reportedly without valid evidence, in violation of FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( 7 ). Requires removal. 

XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$0.00} - As with prior entries, Section 623 mandates removal due to inaccuracies. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX - Account # : XXXX - Balance : {$100.00} - A medical collection in violation of 15 US Code 1681a ( 3 ) and must not appear on my credit report. 

The law requires you to respond to my dispute within 30 days of receipt of this letter. If after your investigation, any of the above-listed items can not be verified or are found to be inaccurate, they must be corrected or deleted immediately. 
If you require further documentation to assist in your investigation, please contact me promptly so that I may provide it. I expect to hear back from you with the results of your investigation. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to these serious concerns. 

Sincerely, Attachments : police reports, ID, Proof address, SSN, Dispute letter

Consumer complaint narrative:
To whom this may concern, After reviewing my credit reports I noticed that you are alleging that the following accounts are negative without furnishing any proof of verification of this debt or that you followed all laws and regulations to report therefore you must remove all negative and adverse remarks. 

The inaccuracies involve the following accounts : From XXXX XXXX XXXX - **Account Number : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Miss payment - **Account Number : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Miss Payment As you know it is against the law to report any information not proven accurate.

I demand that you provide me with concrete evidence of my obligation to said accounts.

( If These Matters Have Been properly taken care of please disregard ) Please be aware that all negative remarks found on my credit report is a violation of the FCRA and FDCPA when you can not furnish the validity of the remark. 
I am not in dispute of the ownership of the account but if you are unable to provide the full reports of how you validated, verified, and how you are in compliance then you must remove the negative information or the account from my credit report. Also According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 a states " There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' XXXX and Experian are consumer reporting agencies and I Am the Consumer. Which would certainly have the right to Assert that my private information is not shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states " It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. '' is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 ( a ) section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' The financial institution and the Consumer reporting agencies XXXX and Experian do not have my consent to furnish this information and they surely do not have my written consent. Any and all consent to XXXX, Experian, whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise. that nondisclosure option. '' i was Never informed of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), but no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A states " A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S. Code 1681e states '' Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. XXXX and Experian are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that " A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. '' I am opting out of your reporting services.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint against XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax for inaccurate reporting of a charged-off debt, violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ), the Privacy Act of 1974, and the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ). 


XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX has reported a charged-off debt to XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax on my credit report. This is in violation of the FDCPA, which states that when an account is more than 180 days past due, it must generally be charged off. Despite being charged off, XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX has failed to provide me with a XXXX form, as required by IRS code 4681. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX has violated the FCRA ( 15 US. .Code 1681s2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ) by reporting inaccurate information to the credit bureaus. Specifically, they have reported the charged-off debt without having reasonable cause to believe that the information is accurate. This has severely affected my overall score and financial stability. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX actions also violate the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ) - 12 CFR 31.3 and the CFPA 's prohibition against unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices. By continuing to report the charged-off account as a debt, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX is engaging in deceptive conduct that harms consumers ( XXXX ). 

Furthermore, XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX has violated my rights under the Privacy Act of 1974. The Privacy Act of 1974, as amended, 5 U.S.C. 552a, establishes a code of fair information practices that governs the collection, maintenance, use, and dissemination of information about individuals that is maintained in systems of records by federal agencies. A system of records is a group of records under the control of an agency from which information is retrieved by the name of the individual or by some identifier assigned to the individual. The Privacy Act prohibits the disclosure of a record about an individual from a system of records absent the written consent of the individual, unless the disclosure is pursuant to XXXX of XXXX statutory exceptions. XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX improperly disclosed my personal information to credit reporting agencies, specifically XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax without my permission. 

Additionally, XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX has violated the GLBA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802, also known as section 502 ( b ) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ) by failing to provide me with a clear and conspicuous notice of their intent to share my nonpublic personal information with nonaffiliated third parties, such as XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax. This coincides with 16 CFR 313.7 ( Form of opt out notice to consumers ; opt out methods ) 16 CFR 313.10 ( Limits on disclosure of non-public personal information to nonaffiliated third parties ) and 248.124 ( Reasonable opportunity to opt out ). 

Supporting Documentation : Credit Reports to Show Lack of Unison and Accurate Reporting Opt Out Letter to XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX that was ignored FDCPA Documentation concerning charge-off statuses Requested Relief : I request that the CFPB investigate this matter and take appropriate action against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax. I seek the removal of the inaccurate information from my credit report, as well as compensation deemed appropriate and upholding the law per violation committed.

15 U.S. Code 1691i ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general if, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information as appropriate, based on the results of the investigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Consumer complaint narrative: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602a states " There is a need to insure that the consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumer 's rights to privacy. '' XXXX, Equifax and XXXX are consumer reporting agencies and I am the Consumer. I have the right to make sure my private information isn't shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states " It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers ' nonpublic personal information. '' ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604a section 2 states that " in general subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) the financial institutions and the consumer reporting agencies XXXX and XXXX do not have my consent to furnish this information and they surely do not have my written consent. Any and all consent to XXXX, XXXX, whether it be verbal, non verbal, written, implied or other wise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic information to a nonaffiliated third party unless-the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' Credit One Bank, First Access Bank, and Capital One Bank ) never informed me of my right to exercise my non-disclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states 'Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information. Any other adverse item of information, other than records of the convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' These accounts are adverse items they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. code 1681 e states " Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681 c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports under section 1681 b of this title. '' XXXX, Equifax and XXXX are not maintaining reasonable procedures.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Account information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX Pennsylvania XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, Equifax XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX. 

For the past 24 months i have submitted certified letter dispute pointing out to the company 1692 FCRA violations REGARDING THE ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF CRA REPORTING INACCURATELY ON MY CREDIT FILE. 

yet they refuse to remove the in accurate INCOMPLET information and account. I have even seek the CFPB assistance SEVERAL TIMES and the inaccurate accounts remains. 
I have been documenting all certified disputes as well as the response given on this CFPB portal. I intend to include as exhibits in my FCRA complaint in federal court if necessary. 

For the last time please take a look at my attachment and follow along : Item # XXXX XXXX  # XXXX REFORTING TWICE ITEM XXXX XXXX  # XXXX Reporting twice XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX have been reporting account with {$XXXX} balance twice on my credit report for the past 36 months. Once again they reported the same account closed several times twice. closed on XX/XX/XXXX, closed on XX/XX/XXXX and reporting as XXXX seperate accounts on credit report : All three agency reporting the same account last payment as : XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX ( see the attached ) Questions : 1 How can you verify the same account numbers reporting twice on a credit report? 2. How can you say you call the company and verified reporting inaccurate information? 3. How can you close the same account twice at the same time on a credit report? 4. How can the last payment be five ( 5 ) different dates and year??? 


Item # XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  # XXXX I have never have an account or done business with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  furthermore ALL CRA IS REPORTING DIFFERENT INFORMATION REGARDING THIS ACCOUNT : Different date account was open, different balance owed, different date of last payment, different date account was closed. 

I have ask for proof but unable to receive a contract from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, they have no record of me signing any contract with them. Yet the credit reporting agency keep verifying inaccurate information and refused to delete. 

Item # XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. ALL THREE CRA reporting. different balance, different date account was open, different date of last payment etc. 

# XXXX XXXX XXXX # XXXX Inaccurate information I now have enough credit reports to prove FCRA and FDCPA violations and damages done to my credit and life which also include the many times i disputed with the CFPB. 

# XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  # XXXX Fraudulent account with different information reporting on all CRA regarding the same account. 

CRA have all failed to mark the disputed items disputed, another FCRA violation Rather than wasting time on a lawsuit i keep pointing out these errors yet they willingly refuse to remove the inaccurate information from my credit report. 

They have all failed to mark each disputed items DISPUTED another FCRA and FDCPA violation which continues to cause damages to me : compensatory and punitive damages. 

PS : I am in possession of all credit reports and the response given by all CRA to prove the violations and errors mentioned in all my disputes to the CFPB. 

I am giving them another chance to remove/Delete the disputed items before filing a claim in the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX. 

I will be asking for relief to include compensatory and punitive damages if they continue to report inaccurately and incomplete reporting. 

EXHIBITS 1. Credit Reports 24 months 2. Certified Mailings 3. Written responses from CRA 4. Copies of all CFPB complaint and response from company

Consumer complaint narrative: I am writing to dispute the accuracy of the hard inquiries listed on my credit report provided by XXXX as allowed under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. 1681. I have identified several inquiries that are inaccurate and request their immediate removal from my credit report. I have not authorized any of these companies listed XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX I request that these discrepancies are investigated promptly and remove the inaccurate inquiries from my credit report.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Account information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am reaching out to you in a state of utter desperation. The inaccuracies on my credit report have shattered my dreams, torn apart my sense of security, and left me in a constant state of anxiety. My life is unraveling before my eyes, and I dont know where else to turn. 

I recently filed complaints ( Complaint IDs : XXXX, XXXX, XXXX ) concerning several accounts that are inaccurately reported on my credit file. Despite my best efforts, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX  XXXX XXXX have told me they can not even find my accounts, leaving me helpless in providing details that I dont have. How can I defend myself against something they claim doesnt exist? 

Because of these errors, my life is falling apart. The car I need to go to work and the home Ive dreamt of owning are both slipping through my fingers. I am mentally and emotionally broken. The weight of this situation is unbearable, and I fear that it could destroy everything Ive worked so hard to build. 

The accounts in question are as follows : XXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX These accounts are wrongly holding me XXXX, violating my federally protected rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681. I reviewed my Experian credit report on XXXX XXXX XXXX and was devastated to find glaring inaccuracies that are completely beyond my control. 

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 15 USC 1681 ( e ) ( b ), consumer reporting agencies are legally required to follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information in consumer reports. Additionally, under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ), if disputed information is found to be inaccurate or unverifiable, it must be promptly deleted or corrected. And yet, despite these clear legal protections, I remain trapped in this nightmare.

Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681s-2, furnishers are prohibited from providing information they know or have reasonable cause to believe is inaccurate. And yet, my life is being destroyed by false information that continues to haunt me. 

My Previous Complaint Details : Complaint ID : XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX ID : XXXX ( Experian ) Complaint ID : XXXX ( XXXX ) These complaints remain unresolved, and the inaccuracies persist, wreaking havoc on my life. I am begging youplease, remove this inaccurate information from my credit report. I feel like Im drowning in a sea of injustice, with no way out. This is not just a matter of numbers on a report ; this is my life, my future, and my sanity at stake. I can not bear this burden any longer. 

Please help me fix this before its too late. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am reaching out to you in a state of utter desperation. The inaccuracies on my credit report have shattered my dreams, torn apart my sense of security, and left me in a constant state of anxiety. My life is unraveling before my eyes, and I dont know where else to turn. 

I recently filed complaints ( Complaint IDs : XXXX, XXXX, XXXX ) concerning several accounts that are inaccurately reported on my credit file. Despite my best efforts, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX have told me they can not even find my accounts, leaving me helpless in providing details that I dont have. How can I defend myself against something they claim doesnt exist? 

Because of these errors, my life is falling apart. The car I need to go to work and the home Ive dreamt of owning are both slipping through my fingers. I am mentally and emotionally broken. The weight of this situation is unbearable, and I fear that it could destroy everything Ive worked so hard to build. 

The accounts in question are as follows : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX These accounts are wrongly holding me hostage, violating my federally protected rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681. I reviewed my XXXX credit report on XXXX XXXX XXXX, and was devastated to find glaring inaccuracies that are completely beyond my control. 

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 15 USC 1681 ( e ) ( b ), consumer reporting agencies are legally required to follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information in consumer reports. Additionally, under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ), if disputed information is found to be inaccurate or unverifiable, it must be promptly deleted or corrected. And yet, despite these clear legal protections, I remain trapped in this nightmare. 

Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681s-2, furnishers are prohibited from providing information they know or have reasonable cause to believe is inaccurate. And yet, my life is being destroyed by false information that continues to haunt me. 

My Previous Complaint Details : Complaint ID : XXXX ( TransUnion ) XXXX ID : XXXX ( XXXX ) Complaint ID : XXXX ( XXXX ) These complaints remain unresolved, and the inaccuracies persist, wreaking havoc on my life. I am begging youplease, remove this inaccurate information from my credit report. I feel like Im drowning in a sea of injustice, with no way out. This is not just a matter of numbers on a report ; this is my life, my future, and my sanity at stake. I can not bear this burden any longer. 

Please help me fix this before its too late. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Notice to agent is notice to principal notice to principal is notice to agent You [ XXXX, XXXX, XXXX replied that the alleged transaction you furnished as late was { accurate/ verified } but my previous dispute did not ask you for accuracy or validation. 
You { XXXX, XXXX, XXXX } reported an alleged transaction as Late. 
15 U.S. Code 1666b - Timing of payments ( a ) TIME TO MAKE PAYMENTS Acreditormay not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless thecreditorhas adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required bysection 1637 ( b ) of this titleis mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. 
15 USC 1681e ( b ) ( b ) ACCURACY OF REPORT Whenever aconsumer reporting agencyprepares aconsumer reportit shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. 

I requested the information that you must have or possess by law in order for you to report a payment as late.

This is being request pursuant rule 1002.

In other words, to properly report information as verified, the furnisher must have sufficient evidence to support the conclusion that the information was true, and in doing this the co
nditions required by 15 USC 1666b must be met.

You failed to provide the required requested information, you failed to proceed in accordance with the requires for a creditor to treat a payment as late and the evidence that must be sent to you to prove that this transaction was late.
It has been over 30 days and you have not properly verify the information.

Id. at 1303 ; see also XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. 2019 ) ( defining verify as [ t ] o prove to be true ; to confirm or establish the truth or truthfulness of ; to authenticate ).

15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( a ) REINVESTIGATIONS OF DISPUTED
INFORMATION ( 1 ) REINVESTIGATION REQUIRED ( A ) In general Subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), if the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in aconsumersfileat aconsumer reporting agencyis disputed by theconsumerand theconsumernotifies the agency directly, or indirectly through areseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate andrecordthe current status of the disputed information, or del
ete the item from thefilein accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from theconsumerorreseller. 

Importantly, a furnishers inability to conclusively determine that the disputed information is inaccurate does not mean that the furnisher is permitted to report back to the consumer reporting agency that its investigation verified the accuracy of that information. Instead, if the evidence available to the furnisher is insufficient to establish the truth or falsity of the disputed information, then, under the statutory framework, the furnisher must report that its investigation concluded that the disputed information can not be verified.

Hinkle, 827 F.3d at 1304. So, for example, if a furnisher is unable to verify that a consumer missed a payment, then it may be appropriate for the furnisher to delete any mentions of the missed payment while continuing to report other information about the account.

I am requesting pursuant 15 USC 1681i ( 6 ) NOTICE OF RESULTS OF REINVESTIGATION ( B ) Contents ( iii ) a notice that, if requested by theconsumer, a description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information shall be provided to theconsumerby the agency, including the business name and address of any furnisher of information contacted in connection with such information and the telephone number of such furnisher.

when disputed information can not be verified is to delete that information.
In particular, Section 1681i outlines consumer reporting agencies responsibilities in responding to consumers disputes and, like Section 1681s-2 ( b ), provides that when a disputed item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency must delete or modify it as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ).

Section 1681i goes on to provide that, [ f ] ollowing any deletion of information which is found to be inaccurate or whose accuracy can no longer be verified, the consumer reporting agency must in some circumstances notify certain people who previously received a report with the now-deleted information. That provision thus contemplates that when information can no longer be verified, the proper response is to delet [ e ] it. See Hinkle, 827 F.3d at 1304 Delete the information you are Reporting as Late from account.

In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am writing to file a formal complaint against the following accounts listed on my credit reports, which have violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681. These violations are detailed below : Violations : 15 U.S.C 1681 Section 602 ( a ) : This section affirms my right to privacy, which has been compromised by the improper furnishing and handling of my personal information.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 ( a ) ( 2 ) : This section clearly states that a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions, which has not been provided in these cases.

15 U.S.C 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) : This section prohibits the inclusion of any adverse information in a consumer report that is more than seven years old. The accounts listed below contain adverse information that predates the legally allowed time frame.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) : This section prohibits the furnishing of information that is known to be inaccurate. The accounts listed below contain inaccuracies that have been reported despite reasonable cause to believe they were incorrect.

15 U.S.C. 6802 : I did not receive the required opt-out notice at the time of account creation, which violates my right to opt-out from the reporting of non-public information.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Recently, I did an investigation on my credit report and found several items on there to be inaccurate.

Under 15 U.S Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report. It shall follow reasonable procedures to assure the maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

15 U.S. Code 1691i ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general if, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information as appropriate, based on the results of the investigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Regarding Failure of Credit Bureau to Reinvestigate and Remove Inaccurate Late Payment Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Experian, XXXX, XXXX for their failure to properly reinvestigate and remove an inaccurate late payment from my credit report, as required under federal law. 
I noticed a late payment entry on my credit report for my account with XXXX, which I believe is incorrect. I immediately disputed this entry with Experian, XXXX, XXXX and provided all necessary documentation to support my claim, including payment records and correspondence with XXXX Under 15 USC 1666 ( b ), I am entitled to a prompt investigation of disputed billing errors, and under 15 USC 1681 ( a ) ( 2 ) ( A ), the credit bureau is obligated to ensure the accuracy of the information reported. Despite these clear legal requirements, Experian, XXXX, XXXX has failed to adequately reinvestigate my dispute and has left the incorrect late payment on my credit report. 

This error is causing me significant distress and negatively affecting my creditworthiness. I request that the CFPB take immediate action to ensure that Experian, XXXX, XXXX complies with the legal obligations outlined in 15 USC 1666 ( b ) and 15 USC 1681 ( a ) ( 2 ) ( A ), and that the incorrect late payment is promptly removed from my credit report. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and look forward to a resolution. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Public record information inaccurate
Consumer complaint narrative: Bankruptcy is not mine, and the credit bureaus won't delete them. They all said they verified it through XXXX. XXXX says they got the information from XXXX, but XXXX says they don't supply information to third-party sources. So how is it verified if it's mine if the source doesn't supply the information? Given that XXXX  does not provide information to third-party sources, the verification process by XXXX and the credit bureaus does not meet the " reasonable procedures '' standard required by the FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681.So if XXXX and the credit bureaus can not verify the bankruptcy through a reliable and accurate source ( since XXXX  does not provide this information to third parties ), they are required by law to delete it from my credit report.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern : I recently received a copy of my ( XXXX, XXXX or TransUnion ) consumer report, and I noticed that it is reporting my experience with your company. 

The line of credit I have with your company, which is characterized as utilization on my consumer reports.

List Name of the accounts with high Utilizations along with their account numbers. 
XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX Your company is in clear violation of the law. Utilization is an experience with the line of credit that was extended between the consumer ( ME ) and the person ( YOU ) [ XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ] that is making the report. CONGRESS clearly states that the experiences between the CONSUMER and the PERSON making the report is not included on the consumer reports! 
YOU HAVE VIOLATED THE FCRA 15USC 1681a 2Ai by reporting this transaction or experience ( Utilization ) on my consumer reports which CONGRESS clearly states IS NOT included on my CONSUMER REPORTS. 
You have 10 calendar days to update my utilization to 5 % or below and or delete all Utilization from the below account/s XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX Failure to respond satisfactorily with deletion of the above Utilization, will result in legal actions being taken against your company, for which I will also be seeking {$1000.00} per violation for : 1. Civil liability for willful noncompliance [ 15 U.S.C. 1681n ] Best regards, Your Name XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Public record information inaccurate
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to lodge an urgent and forceful complaint against XXXX, Experian, and XXXX regarding their persistent failure to remove an inaccurate bankruptcy entry from my credit reports ; Account number XXXX. Despite my numerous efforts to provide ample and irrefutable evidence proving the error, these credit bureaus have unacceptably continued to display this erroneous information. 

This process began in XXXX of 2023, yes a full year and they have not resolved it, where I disputed with the court ( attached ). The court states that it doe snot supply information to the Bureaus. I submitted Disputed to XXXX, Experian, and XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX, to no avail. When they finally sent information back, they stated that it is verified by a 3rd party called XXXX XXXX. So I submitted a dispute to XXXX XXXX in XXXX. XXXX XXXX said I was correct about the inaccurate bankruptcy and removed it from their files ( attached documentation ). I submitted another Dispute to the bureaus in XXXX with the letters sent by XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX said it was verified, which is impossible. XXXX and Experian did not even respond ( illegals ) Here is a summary of the egregious missteps by the credit bureaus : Failure to Correct Errors : Despite providing all necessary evidence, each bureau has inexplicably failed to correct the inaccuracy. Their responses have been dismissive and inadequate, lacking any substantive action to rectify the mistake. 

Negligent Handling of Disputes : The process followed by the credit bureaus in handling my dispute has been grossly inefficient and unprofessional. Their failure to resolve the dispute in a timely manner reflects a troubling disregard for consumer rights. 

Impact on Creditworthiness : The erroneous bankruptcy record is significantly damaging my creditworthiness and, consequently, my financial stability. This ongoing issue has led to undue stress and has negatively impacted my ability to secure credit.

I demand immediate action to rectify this situation. Specifically, I require : Prompt Removal : Immediate removal of the inaccurate bankruptcy entry from all three credit reports. 

Written Confirmation : Written confirmation from each credit bureau acknowledging the removal and detailing the corrective actions taken. 

Investigation and Accountability : A thorough investigation into the handling of my dispute, including a detailed explanation of why my evidence was ignored and what measures will be implemented to prevent such issues in the future. 

If these demands are not met within 15 days from the date of this letter, I will be compelled to escalate this matter further, including but not limited to seeking legal redress and filing formal complaints with additional regulatory bodies. 

The lack of action and accountability from XXXX, Experian, and XXXX is unacceptable and reflects a serious breach of my consumer rights. I trust that the CFPB will act swiftly to ensure that this matter is resolved with the seriousness it warrants.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Personal information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to bring to your attention a serious issue with my credit report that I have been unable to resolve despite multiple attempts. My credit report contains an incorrect name and address, and there are accounts listed under this incorrect information that do not belong to me. I have only one correct name and one correct address, which I have provided above.

1. Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1681 The inclusion of incorrect name and address information on my credit report violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which mandates that credit reporting agencies maintain accurate and complete information. Under the FCRA, I have the right to dispute inaccurate information, and the credit reporting agencies are required to investigate and correct these errors within 30 days.

2. Violation of the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act ( FACTA ) - Address Discrepancy Rules The incorrect information on my credit report also implicates the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act ( FACTA ). The Act requires that any substantial discrepancies in address information be addressed and resolved by the credit reporting agencies. Failure to comply with these provisions can result in significant harm to consumers.

3. Potential Financial Compensation for Violations Under the FCRA, if the credit reporting agencies fail to correct these errors or continue to report inaccurate information, I may be entitled to monetary compensation. Specifically : Actual Damages : I may recover actual damages incurred as a result of the errors, such as increased interest rates, denied credit, or other financial losses.

Statutory Damages : In cases of willful non-compliance, I may be entitled to statutory damages ranging from {$100.00} to {$1000.00} per violation.

Punitive Damages : In cases of willful or reckless violations, the court may award punitive damages.

Attorneys Fees and Costs : The FCRA also allows for the recovery of attorneys fees and court costs if legal action becomes necessary.

4. Request for Deletion of Incorrect Accounts As a result of these violations, there are accounts associated with the incorrect name and address that do not belong to me. I am formally requesting that all accounts linked to the incorrect name and address be deleted from my credit report.

5. Previous Attempts to Resolve I have reached out to the credit reporting agenciesXXXX, Experian, and XXXX multiple occasions to address these errors. Unfortunately, I have not received any responses or confirmation that these issues have been addressed. The lack of response is not only frustrating but also constitutes further non-compliance with federal law.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, data furnishers are required to provide complete and accurate information to credit reporting agencies. Reporting an incorrect or inflated amount, particularly after a charge-off, constitutes a violation of this statute. If the balance includes fees, interest, or charges that are unlawful or inaccurately represented, it must be corrected or removed from my credit report. 
Violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) Furthermore, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), 15 U.S. Code 1692e ( 2 ), debt collectors are prohibited from making false or misleading representations about the amount, character, or legal status of a debt. If the reported amount includes unlawful fees, interest, or other charges, it is a violation of this federal law. My rights have been violated under the Fair Debt Collection Practice Act and Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2

Consumer complaint narrative:
Notice to agent is notice to principal notice to principal is notice to agent You [ Experian, XXXX, XXXX replied that the alleged transaction you furnished as late was { accurate/ verified } but my previous dispute did not ask you for accuracy or validation. 
On { XX/XX/XXXX } you { Experian, XXXX, XXXX } reported an alleged transaction as Late.

15 U.S. Code 1666b - Timing of payments ( a ) TIME TO MAKE PAYMENTS Acreditormay not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless thecreditorhas adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required bysection 1637 ( b ) of this titleis mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date.

15 USC 1681e ( b ) ( b ) ACCURACY OF REPORT Whenever aconsumer reporting agencyprepares aconsumer reportit shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

I requested the information that you must have or possess by law in order for you to report a payment as late.

This is being request pursuant rule 1002.

In other words, to properly report information as verified, the furnisher must have sufficient evidence to support the conclusion that the information was true, and in doing this the conditions required by 15 USC 1666b must be met.

You failed to provide the required requested information, you failed to proceed in accordance with the requires for a creditor to treat a payment as late and the evidence that must be sent to you to prove that this transaction was late.

It has been over 30 days and you have not properly verify the information. 
Id. at XXXX ; see also XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) ( defining verify as [ t ] o prove to be true ; to confirm or establish the truth or truthfulness of ; to authenticate ).

15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( a ) REINVESTIGATIONS OF DISPUTED INFORMATION ( 1 ) REINVESTIGATION REQUIRED ( A ) In general Subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), if the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in aconsumersfileat aconsumer reporting agencyis disputed by theconsumerand theconsumernotifies the agency directly, or indirectly through areseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate andrecordthe current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from thefilein accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from theconsumerorreseller.

Importantly, a furnishers inability to conclusively determine that the disputed information is inaccurate does not mean that the furnisher is permitted to report back to the consumer reporting agency that its investigation verified the accuracy of that information. Instead, if the evidence available to the furnisher is insufficient to establish the truth or falsity of the disputed information, then, under the statutory framework, the furnisher must report that its investigation concluded that the disputed information can not be verified.

Hinkle, 827 F.3d at 1304. So, for example, if a furnisher is unable to verify that a consumer missed a payment, then it may be appropriate for the furnisher to delete any mentions of the missed payment while continuing to report other information about the account.

I am requesting pursuant 15 USC 1681i ( 6 ) NOTICE OF RESULTS OF REINVESTIGATION ( B ) Contents ( iii ) a notice that, if requested by theconsumer, a description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information shall be provided to theconsumerby the agency, including the business name and address of any furnisher of information contacted in connection with such information and the telephone number of such furnisher.

when disputed information can not be verified is to delete that information.

In particular, Section 1681i outlines consumer reporting agencies responsibilities in responding to consumers disputes and, like Section 1681s-2 ( b ), provides that when a disputed item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency must delete or modify it as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ).

Section 1681i goes on to provide that, [ f ] ollowing any deletion of information which is found to be inaccurate or whose accuracy can no longer be verified, the consumer reporting agency must in some circumstances notify certain people who previously received a report with the now-deleted information. That provision thus contemplates that when information can no longer be verified, the proper response is to delet [ XXXX ] it. See XXXX 827 F.3d at 1304 Delete the information you are Reporting as Late from account : XXXX  XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, XXXX XXXX _________________________________ Without Recourse UCC XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern : I recently received a copy of my credit report and I noticed some account/s on my consumer report that should not be on there. I demand the below accounts deleted from my consumer report immediately. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The reporting of these account ( s ) is/are violations of 15 USC 1681a , The Fair Credit Reporting Act [ 15 USC 1681 ( a ) ( 2 ) ( B ) ] : ( 2 ) EXCLUSIONS.Except as provided in paragraph ( 3 ), the term consumer report does not include ( B ) any authorization or approval of a specific extension of credit directly or indirectly by the issuer of a credit card or similar device ; So let me explain. Under the Truth in Lending Act 15 USC 1602 ( g ), credit card is defined as the following : The term credit card means any card, plate, coupon book or other credit device existing for the purpose of obtaining money, property, labor, or services on credit. 
This makes my social security card, drivers license/ID, and license plate credit cards that are/were used for the extension of credit. 
I am writing in regard to the above-referenced account/s and transactions. This vehicle was purchased at ( dealership name ) Date ( the date it was purchased ). 
I have recently come across inform from the Federal trade Commission ( FTC ) more specifically the GrammLeachBliley Act 15 usc 6802 obligations with respect to disclosures of personal information ( a ) NOTICE REQUIREMENTS Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, a financial institution may not, directly or through any affiliate, disclose to a nonaffiliated third party any nonpublic personal information, unless such financial institution provides or has provided to the consumer a notice that complies with section 6803 of this title. 
( b ) OPT OUT ( XXXX ) IN XXXXENERALA financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless ( A ) such financial institution clearly and conspicuously discloses to the consumer, in writing or in electronic form or other form permitted by the regulations prescribed under section 6804 of this title, that such information may be disclosed to such third party ; ( B ) the consumer is given the opportunity, before the time that such information is initially disclosed, to direct that such information not be disclosed to such third party ; and ( C ) the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. 
( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX did not disclose this information to me that is required by federal law.

Im a victim of debt bondage due to human trafficking, and Ive been working with an advocacy group to get support. According to guidance from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and the Trafficking-Debt Final Rule, Im entitled to have this information blocked and removed. According to the guidance from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), I have provided the necessary documentation, including a picture ID, a bill, and a letter from an advocacy group assisting me with my situation related to human trafficking and debt bondage. This falls under the Trafficking-Debt Final Rule ( 1002.142 ( b ) ( 4 ) 1002.142 ( b ) ( 7 ) ).

I kindly request that you block the relevant information from my credit report within four business days, as specified in Section 605C of the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I have submitted all required documents, including the identification and information from the list of acceptable items, and a victim determination letter in accordance with 1022.142 ( b ) ( 6 ).

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Specifically, I need the following account removed from my credit report within four business days, as outlined in Section 605C of the Fair Credit Reporting Act : XXXX XXXX BANK XXXX {$880.00} Your understanding and prompt action on this matter would mean a great deal to me. Thank you for your help.

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, CA XXXX XX/XX/2024 Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington XXXX DC XXXX Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Accounts and Hard Inquiries Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding inaccurate and outdated information on my credit report, in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). The following accounts have violated my federally protected consumer rights under 15 U.S.C. 1681, and I am requesting their removal : Accounts in Dispute : XXXX  Account Number : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : 15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 602 A : I have the right to privacy. 
15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 604 A ( 2 ) : A consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions.

15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) : No consumer reporting agency may include information that is over 7 years old.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) : Information furnished to consumer reporting agencies must be accurate. 
Additional Concerns : The following hard inquiries on my credit report are also disputed under the FCRA : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  : Unknown. 
XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX Hard inquiry # 1. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX : Hard inquiry # 2. 
According to 15 U.S.C. 1681i and 15 U.S.C. 1681b, these inquiries are past the two-year limit and are not accurate or authorized by me. 

I request that you investigate these accounts and hard inquiries. They should be removed from my credit report as they are either outdated or inaccurately reported. Please provide written confirmation once these items have been removed or inform me if additional information is needed. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

And according to the fair credit reporting act Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates according to 15 USC 1681 ( e ) ( b ).

And according to 15 USC 1681 5 they are suppose to do this ( XXXX ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In generallf, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( XXXX ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer. 

and according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are suppose to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative: Notice to agent is notice to principal notice to principal is notice to agent You [ XXXX, XXXX, XXXX replied that the alleged transaction you furnished as late was { accurate/ verified } but my previous dispute did not ask you for accuracy or validation. You { XXXX, XXXX, XXXX } reported an alleged transaction as Late. 15 U.S. Code 1666b - Timing of payments ( a ) TIME TO MAKE PAYMENTS A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. 15 USC 1681e ( b ) ( b ) ACCURACY OF REPORT Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. I requested the information that you must have or possess by law in order for you to report a payment as late. This is being request pursuant rule 1002. In other words, to properly report information as verified, the furnisher must have sufficient evidence to support the conclusion that the information was true, and in doing this the conditions required by 15 USC 1666b must be met. You failed to provide the required requested information, you failed to proceed in accordance with the requires for a creditor to treat a payment as late and the evidence that must be sent to you to prove that this transaction was late. It has been over 30 days and you have not properly verify the information. Id. at XXXX ; see also Blacks Law Dictionary ( 11th ed. 2019 ) ( defining verify as [ t ] o prove to be true ; to confirm or establish the truth or truthfulness of ; to authenticate ). 15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( a ) REINVESTIGATIONS OF DISPUTED INFORMATION ( XXXX ) REINVESTIGATION REQUIRED ( A ) In general Subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), if the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in a consumers file at a consumer reporting agency is disputed by the consumer and the consumer notifies the agency directly, or indirectly through a reseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate and record the current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from the file in accordance with paragraph ( XXXX ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from the consumer or reseller. Importantly, a furnishers inability to conclusively determine that the disputed information is inaccurate does not mean that the furnisher is permitted to report back to the consumer reporting agency that its investigation verified the accuracy of that information. Instead, if the evidence available to the furnisher is insufficient to establish the truth or falsity of the disputed information, then, under the statutory framework, the furnisher must report that its investigation concluded that the disputed information can not be verified. Hinkle, 827 F.3d at 1304. So, for example, if a furnisher is unable to verify that a consumer missed a payment, then it may be appropriate for the furnisher to delete any mentions of the missed payment while continuing to report other information about the account. I am requesting pursuant 15 USC 1681i ( 6 ) NOTICE OF RESULTS OF REINVESTIGATION ( B ) Contents ( iii ) a notice that, if requested by the consumer, a description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information shall be provided to the consumer by the agency, including the business name and address of any furnisher of information contacted in connection with such information and the telephone number of such furnisher. when disputed information can not be verified is to delete that information. In particular, Section 1681i outlines consumer reporting agencies responsibilities in responding to consumers disputes and, like Section 1681s-2 ( b ), provides that when a disputed item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency must delete or modify it as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ). Section 1681i goes on to provide that, [ f ] ollowing any deletion of information which is found to be inaccurate or whose accuracy can no longer be verified, the consumer reporting agency must in some circumstances notify certain people who previously received a report with the now-deleted information. That provision thus contemplates that when information can no longer be verified, the proper response is to delet [ e ] it. See Hinkle, 827 F.3d at 1304 Delete the information you are Reporting as Late from account. XXXX XXXX _________________________________ Without Recourse UCC 1-308
Company public response: Company can't verify or dispute the facts in the complaint

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Equifax for Violation of Fair Credit Reporting Act Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Equifax for its failure to properly investigate and remove inaccurate account information from my credit report in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 611 ).

Account Information : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Account Number : XXXX Amount : {$480.00} I previously submitted a dispute to Equifax regarding the inaccuracies in the above-referenced account. Despite providing evidence supporting the inaccuracies and requesting its removal from my credit report, Equifax failed to conduct a thorough investigation and the disputed account remains on my credit report. 

As a consumer protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I have the right to request the removal of inaccurate or outdated information from my credit report. Equifax failure to comply with this law is a violation of my consumer rights and has caused me financial harm and distress. 

I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and take appropriate action against Equifax for its non-compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I am seeking the immediate removal of the inaccurate account information from my credit report and appropriate measures to ensure that Equifax upholds its obligations under the law. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a prompt resolution and your assistance in rectifying this issue.

Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to bring to your attention certain inaccuracies on my credit report and to formally notify XXXX of potential legal violations that require immediate attention. 

Identification of Inaccuracies : Upon reviewing my credit report, I have identified several inaccuracies that have adversely affected my financial standing. These inaccuracies include : incorrect balance, late payments, account number, credit limit, date of reported and others inconsistencies. 

Impact on My Financial Well-being : The inaccuracies outlined above have severely affected my creditworthiness and overall financial health. In XX/XX/XXXX, I experienced a major financial setback due to a family emergency, which led me to apply for a personal loan with XXXX XXXX  and other creditors offered loans with significantly high interest rates and I have been wrongfully denied which was highly embarrassing and has negatively impacted my lifestyle. This misinformation has had a detrimental impact on my financial options and opportunities. Would you reinvestigate the accounts listed below. 

Account Name : XXXX  XXXX XXXX Number : XXXX Reinvestigate the completeness of every piece of information and if its not accurate, please remove it from my credit report. 

Reference to Relevant Laws : I believe that these inaccuracies violate consumer protection laws, including but not limited to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). The FCRA mandates accurate reporting and stipulates that consumers have the right to dispute and correct inaccuracies on their credit reports. 
Based of consumer law 15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy, if within 30 days you can not verify the accuracy of the information, please remove the account from my credit report.

Request for Thorough Investigation : I kindly request that XXXX conducts a thorough investigation into the inaccuracies outlined above and takes immediate corrective action. I believe that rectifying these errors is crucial to maintaining the integrity of the credit reporting system and upholding consumer rights. 

Potential Legal Consequences : Please be advised that if these violations are not addressed promptly, I may be compelled to take legal action to protect my rights under the FCRA and other applicable laws.

Optionally with the proof I am attaching to this letter, you will agree it needs to be removed XXXX. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and request that you keep me informed of the progress of your investigation. You may reach me at XXXX XXXX to discuss this further. 

Thank you for your understanding and cooperation. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, NY XXXX XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX SSN : XXXX

And according to the fair credit reporting act Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates according to 15 USC 1681 ( e ) ( b ).

And according to 15 USC 1681 5 they are suppose to do this ( XXXX ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In generallf, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( XXXX ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer. 

and according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are suppose to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Account information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, CA XXXX XXXX XXXX Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Credit Report Information Credit Report Account Number : XXXX Creditor : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Dear CFPB I am writing to formally dispute the inaccurate information on my credit report under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), which gives me the right to dispute information I believe to be inaccurate or incomplete. 

The account in question is from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, a collections company, with which I have no contractual relationship. Specifically, the details are as follows : Account Number : XXXX Balance : {$2400.00} Date Opened : XX/XX/year> Payment Status : Seriously past due/ Assigned to attorney, collection agency, or credit grantor 's internal collection department Last Reported : XX/XX/year> Dispute Basis : No Contractual Relationship : Under 15 U.S. Code 1692e of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), debt collectors are required to report accurate information and must not use any false, deceptive, or misleading representations. I do not have any contractual agreement with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, which invalidates the reporting of this debt on my credit report. 

Inaccurate Reporting of Debt : The FCRA mandates that all information on a consumer 's credit report must be accurate and verifiable. Since there is no contract or agreement between myself and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, the accuracy of this reported debt is in question. Additionally, the absence of payment history and the derogatory information reported without adequate evidence further violates the FCRA. 

Potential Violation of Consumer Rights : The continued reporting of this account as derogatory, without proper verification and in the absence of a valid contract, may constitute a violation of my consumer rights under the FCRA. Additionally, the failure to provide complete information about the payment history and the terms of the alleged debt raises concerns about the legality of this reporting.

Request for Resolution : I request that [ Credit Bureau Name ] conduct a thorough investigation into this matter. If you are unable to verify the accuracy and legality of this information, I demand that this collections account be removed from my credit report immediately.

Please notify me of the outcome of your investigation within the 30-day period as required by the FCRA. If the investigation reveals that the information is inaccurate, I request that the account be removed from my credit report and that I be provided with an updated copy of my report.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. If further information or documentation is required, please do not hesitate to contact me. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am formally disputing the account XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. As mandated by the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), specifically section 1629g, you are legally required to verify this debt. Failure to provide proper verification will result in a violation of federal and state regulations governing debt collection practices. 

Under the FDCPA, your verification must include the following : Proof of my agreement to pay the original creditor ; A copy of the final account statement issued by the original creditor ; A detailed breakdown of the total amount due, including principal, interest, and any additional charges ; Documentation for each charge, including the date and basis for each charge.

I dispute this debt for the following reasons : [ Insert reason ( s ) for dispute ]. 

Given this dispute, you are legally obligated not to report this debt to any credit reporting agencies. If this debt has already been reported, you must immediately notify the credit reporting agencies that the debt is disputed and remove the tradeline from my credit report. Reporting information you know to be inaccurate, or failing to correct such information, constitutes a violation of the FDCPA and the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 

Furthermore, except for providing verification of this debt, you are required by law to cease all communication with me regarding this matter. Any attempt to contact me in violation of this request will be treated as a breach of your legal obligations under the FDCPA. 

This matter demands your immediate attention. I expect full compliance with all legal requirements without delay. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

I have not provided any authorization for the disclosure of my account closure to any consumer reporting agency, and I believe this action is a breach of the privacy protections I am entitled to under the law.

Consumer complaint narrative:
This letter serves as a formal dispute regarding the debt reported on my credit file under Account Number XXXX. This debt is fraudulent, the result of identity theft, and has absolutely no connection to me. I have never opened an account with XXXX XXXX XXXX, nor have I ever authorized anyone to do so on my behalf. The presence of this erroneous and fraudulent information on my credit report is unacceptable and has caused substantial damage to my creditworthiness. 

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I am exercising my legal right to dispute this debt. You are legally obligated to investigate and remove any inaccurate or fraudulent information from my credit file. 

To substantiate my claim of identity theft, I have enclosed the following documentation : A copy of my police report or FTC Identity Theft Report. 
A copy of my government-issued ID to verify my identity. 
I demand the immediate removal of this fraudulent debt from my credit report. If this issue is not resolved promptly, I will not hesitate to take legal action to enforce my rights under the FCRA and FDCPA. This includes filing a complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and pursuing all available legal remedies. 

I expect confirmation in writing that this fraudulent account has been removed from my credit report within 3 days. Failure to comply will result in further legal action. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: Notice to agent is notice to principal notice to principal is notice to agent You [ XXXX, XXXX, XXXX replied that the alleged transaction you furnished as late was { accurate/ verified } but my previous dispute did not ask you for accuracy or validation. You { XXXX, XXXX, XXXX } reported an alleged transaction as Late. 15 U.S. Code 1666b - Timing of payments ( a ) TIME TO MAKE PAYMENTS A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. 15 USC 1681e ( b ) ( b ) ACCURACY OF REPORT Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. I requested the information that you must have or possess by law in order for you to report a payment as late. This is being request pursuant rule 1002. In other words, to properly report information as verified, the furnisher must have sufficient evidence to support the conclusion that the information was true, and in doing this the conditions required by 15 USC 1666b must be met. You failed to provide the required requested information, you failed to proceed in accordance with the requires for a creditor to treat a payment as late and the evidence that must be sent to you to prove that this transaction was late. It has been over 30 days and you have not properly verify the information. Id. at 1303 ; see also Blacks Law Dictionary ( 11th ed. 2019 ) ( defining verify as [ t ] o prove to be true ; to confirm or establish the truth or truthfulness of ; to authenticate ). 15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( a ) REINVESTIGATIONS OF DISPUTED INFORMATION ( 1 ) REINVESTIGATION REQUIRED ( A ) In general Subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), if the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in a consumers file at a consumer reporting agency is disputed by the consumer and the consumer notifies the agency directly, or indirectly through a reseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate and record the current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from the file in accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from the consumer or reseller. Importantly, a furnishers inability to conclusively determine that the disputed information is inaccurate does not mean that the furnisher is permitted to report back to the consumer reporting agency that its investigation verified the accuracy of that information. Instead, if the evidence available to the furnisher is insufficient to establish the truth or falsity of the disputed information, then, under the statutory framework, the furnisher must report that its investigation concluded that the disputed information can not be verified. Hinkle, 827 F.3d at 1304. So, for example, if a furnisher is unable to verify that a consumer missed a payment, then it may be appropriate for the furnisher to delete any mentions of the missed payment while continuing to report other information about the account. I am requesting pursuant 15 USC 1681i ( 6 ) NOTICE OF RESULTS OF REINVESTIGATION ( B ) Contents ( iii ) a notice that, if requested by the consumer, a description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information shall be provided to the consumer by the agency, including the business name and address of any furnisher of information contacted in connection with such information and the telephone number of such furnisher. when disputed information can not be verified is to delete that information. In particular, Section 1681i outlines consumer reporting agencies responsibilities in responding to consumers disputes and, like Section 1681s-2 ( b ), provides that when a disputed item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency must delete or modify it as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ). Section 1681i goes on to provide that, [ f ] ollowing any deletion of information which is found to be inaccurate or whose accuracy can no longer be verified, the consumer reporting agency must in some circumstances notify certain people who previously received a report with the now-deleted information. That provision thus contemplates that when information can no longer be verified, the proper response is to delet [ e ] it. See Hinkle, 827 F.3d at 1304 Delete the information you are Reporting as Late from account. XXXX XXXX _________________________________ Without Recourse UCC 1-308
